citation.article-title: Thermococcus aegaeicus sp. nov. and Staphylothermus hellenicus sp. nov., two novel hyperthermophilic archaea isolated from geothermally heated vents off Palaeochori Bay, Milos, Greece.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Staphylothermus hellenicus sp. nov.
Staphylothermus hellenicus (hel.le'ni.cus. Gr. adj. hellenikos, M.L. adj. hellenicus Greek, pertaining to Greece, from where the organism was isolated)
Cells are irregular cocci with a diameter of 0.8-1.3 μm, often growing in large aggregates.
Growth occurs between 70 and 90 °C with an optimum at 85 °C.
Doubling time at 85 °C is about 2.9 h.
pH range of growth is between 4.5 and 7.0 with an optimum around pH 6.
Growth occurs between 2 and 8% NaCl with an optimum at 4%.
Grows with yeast extract as carbon source, but growth on peptone as carbon source is poor.
Growth is absolutely dependent on elemental sulfur.
Sequence analyses place P8T in the family Desulfurococcaceae; DNA-DNA hybridization indicates that it belongs in the genus Staphylothermus.
The type strain was isolated from a geothermally heated sediment at Palaeochori Bay, Milos, Greece located at a depth of 9.4 m.
